title: Which film will win the 2021 Oscar® for Best Motion Picture of the Year?
preds: Copying Ben Zauzmer who has written a book about predicting the Oscars ' Oscarmetrics: The Math Behind the Biggest Night in Hollywood'. His model has a very good record of predicting the correct outcomes.

Recent anti-establishment sentiment has resulted in greater support for media portraying morally superior public revolts (Chicago 7), especially against police forces. Sound of Metal appeals to mental health issues which is growing in public awareness.
Convincing nyt take about Chicago 7 (last time film won best picture without getting any other Oscar nods)

P("Drama" winning |it wasnt nominated for Golden Globe) = 14%
P("Drama" winning | it won Golden globe) = 13%
P("Bio-Drama" winning | it was golden globe nominated) = 21% Give/take weight for crowd forecast (Mank and Nomadland)

The breadth of untold American stories in Nomadland seems appropriate for these times and the turmoil in the U.S. It also helps that the lead is Oscar winning actress Frances McDormand, and the director is a Chinese national who has been critical of Beijing.

Come on now... Lest we forget re: "Mank" ...Hollywood loves films about Hollywood. 
The crowd will likely be correct, but the overconfidence is a bit silly. Nomadland
GJO: 100% | Experts: 74% |MC users: 67% = Avg. 80.33% Mank:

https://www.metacritic.com/feature/picks-for-who-will-win-2021-oscars?ref=hp

Vegas odds highest on Nomadland. Moved Mank higher than vegas because the academy historically votes for films about the industry. Minari skewed up due to the cultural phenomenon it’s become (a potential Parasite or Moonlight situation).

There seem to be no eclectic-type films on the roster (my opinion, of course), and bio/historical dramas have the edge on other categories (over past 30 years). Also, more often than not, over last thirty years, films win that Golden Globe best picture lose the Oscars best picture more than half of the time. Wisdom of the crowd says Nomadland, though.

The predictions favor Nomadland, however it didn't win for the SAG awards best ensemble.  This predicts the Oscar best picture ~50% of the time. https://variety.com/feature/2021-oscars-best-picture-predictions-1234768047/

Primero, considerando que nunca en las más de 90 premiaciones ha habido un empate en esta categoría, la última opción la descarté. 
Busqué el número de nominaciones que han tenido en la misma categoría pero en distintas premiaciones, siendo (6, 3, 4, 11, 24, 10, 11, 10)
Busqué también el número de nominaciones que tienen en otras categorías de los Óscar (5, 5, 9, 5, 5, 4, 5, 5)
También busqué la puntuación asignada a cada película por parte de RottenTomatoes e IMBd (98% + 8,3/10 ; 96% + 7,6/10 ; 83% + 7/10 ; 98% + 7,6/10 ; 94% + 7,5/10 ; 90% + 7,5/10 ; 97% + 7,8/10 ; 89% + 7,8/10)
Finalmente, en base a esta información es que pude armar mis predicciones, con Nomadland en la delantera. Cabe destacar que esta película ganó la versión del 2020 del Toronto Film Festival, el cual históricamente se lo han ganado muchos ganadores del Óscar de Mejor Película.

Para hacer esta predicción me basé en los siguientes datos:
- Recepción por parte de la crítica
-Número de nominaciones totales en los Oscar
-Número de nominaciones totales (contando varias premiaciones)
-Premios ganados en otras premiaciones (tanto el número como la categoría) A partir de estos datos, se puede ver que "Nomadland" es la película más probable (y la favorita) a ganar. Ha ganado una gran cantidad de premios, incluyendo los más importantes entregados hasta ahora (mejor película y mejor director en los 'Golden Globe awards'), además de que ha sido muy bien recibida por la crítica. Todos estos datos apuntan que va a ser la película ganadora.

Most articles and predictions seem to indicate that Nomadland will win best picture in the 2021 Oscars. However what most if not all of them share is Minari possibly winning, but it's put as an opset. Nomadland seems to be the leading candidate.
Nomadland seems to be the heavy favorite.
The only movie of these that I have seen is the Chicago 7, so I went with the crowd forecast.

There were only six ties in history
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Academy_Award_records#Tied_winners
which would be a baseline of 0.1%, and none of these were in the "Big Five categories".
However, an unexpected tie for two likewise brillant motion pictures may accur, or any other event that could disrupt the Academy Awards on short notice.
Looked at Vegas betting odds and adjusted slightly based on my own sense (which already had Nomadland in the lead. [1] https://www.vegasinsider.com/awards/odds/oscars/

Nomadland is still the frontrunner but Trial won ensemble at Screen Actors Guild awards. Woman, Nomad, and Father didn't pick up much track. Sound of Metal is not really much talked about but it has the leading actor nom, supporting actor nom, screenplay nom, and editing nom.
Oscar predictions have Nomadland edging out Promising Young Woman for best picture. https://variety.com/feature/2021-oscars-best-picture-predictions-1234768047/

We looked at the implied odds on betting websites for underlying probabilities such IMDb, Betfair etc. Another weight was also created using qualitative features of past Oscar winners such as audience rating, directors previously nominated. The results above are derived from the multiplication of the two criteria we created.
Lots of positive press and compelling immigrant story
Did more digging. Looks like Nomadland has a more solid lead than I had thought, and the crowd may be correct this year after floops predicting the Oscars on GJO.

Updated to increase odds for Minari, Nomadland, and Promising Young Woman - the top three frontrunners being nominated across film festivals in America. This means a slight decrease for The Trial of the Chicago 7. For my next update, I will deliberate whether Minari does indeed have the edge due to the ensemble noms, acting noms, screenplay noms, etc. It is missing an editing nomination but Nomadland did not get a WGA nomination. Plus, Google Trends indicates more interest in Minari over the past week, day, and in Los Angeles, where the ceremony is to be held. My gut also tells me Minari's trailer is more friendly, likeable, and relatable than Nomadland. The Oscars also likes leads that seem patriarchal in nature (the surrogate father in Moonlight, Birdman, The King's Speech, . . .).
Nomadland is lacking a Writer's Guild nomination and The Father did not make AFI or NBR list. Adjusted for these reasons.

The Trial of the Chicago 7, compared to the other nominees, fits many statistical indicators of winners (ensemble, PGA, DGA, SAG, editing nom, etc., running time, release date, etc.). My main doubts about this movie is that it resides in a competitive Best Picture category, was released on Netflix, has a strong political tones and harsh cut-aways, did not get a Directing nomination, and did not premiere at a major film festival like Cannes, Venice, Toronto, Sundance, TIFF, Telluride, Tribeca, etc. which most Best Picture winners achieve. It currently stands #2 on Gold Derby, which in almost all cases the #1 pick loses to the #2 pick in recent years. One Night in Miami and Ma Rainey's Black Bottom were both snubbed, which are both throwback historical films in a way and this may be a sign that Trial of the Chicago 7 may meet the same fate as the two snubs mentioned. For Minari and Promising Young Woman to still be in hot contention up to this point, I cannot rule those out either. The Father and Judas also made it. Therefore, I cannot rule out that Nomadland may lose to these strong competitors.

Ben Zauzmer has written a book about predicting the Oscars ' Oscarmetrics: The Math Behind the Biggest Night in Hollywood'. His model has a very good record of predicting the correct outcomes. But this is the "weirdest year of Oscar prediction". "From new eligibility rules to new BAFTA voting procedures to a new awards timeline to watching all movies at home, this will be an awards season unlike any other". These are his predictions for nominations (which we now know) overall they were accurate.
https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/predicting-this-years-oscar-nominations-using-just-math From his Twitter feed 2 days ago...
Best Picture: 95% of best picture winners have a best Director nomination. 95% have a screenplay nomination. 83% were up for best film editing. only Nomadland and Promising young women got all three of those. I think another article will be published shortly with his predictions for winners. I want to do my forecast before that comes out so its not complete plagiarism haha. this is based on others' input. Basically I have no idea and haven't researched the films
Of all the votes cast so far, Nomadland is way ahead.  I am forecasting based on Wisdom of the Crowds.

From what I've been following, the 3 front runners are Judas, Minari, and Nomadland. 
Mank and Chicago 7 will have a lot of buzz, but the influx of new, young, diverse members leads me to believe that the rank choice voting will have tighter groupings of the more diverse films at the top.
